data.title: Associate Vs. Bachelor’s - Video Game Design Degrees
data.meta_description: Want to design video games? Learn which video game design degree will get you on the path to success. Explore curriculum, course duration, fees & careers.
data.text:
With an increasing number of gamers worldwide, the video game industry is expected to generate $196 billion in revenue over the next two years. What was once considered a kids’ pastime has transformed into a powerful business. Game engines are even enabling super-fast rendering for VFX in Hollywood productions, too!

Every video game you have ever played is the product of creative energies working in tandem. But who are the folks behind the game, we might ask? What kind of education or training do they have? What kinds of jobs go into bringing their vision to life?

The creation of a game involves two major areas – video game design and development. This article focuses on game designing as a career. Video game design is the process of building the architecture of a video game, from its concept and storyline to characters and levels.

Two Kinds of Video Game Design Programs

To acquire essential video game design skills, you must have a solid foundation in the subject. Most schools in the United States offer two types of degrees that you can choose from: an associate degree and a bachelor’s degree.

All degree programs in video game design are meant to familiarize students with key concepts related to the creative aspects of game making.

Of course, there are a few key differences between an associate program and a bachelor’s degree that you should know to make an informed choice.

Differences Between Game Design Associate Degree & Bachelor’s Degree Programs

The associate degree program is designed to help students acquire elementary video game design skills and explore entry-level careers in the industry. This program is a great choice for anyone looking to become an animator, a character designer, or a video game designer.

The bachelor’s program in game design prepares students for intermediate-level careers by equipping them with advanced skills and mastery over industry-standard software. If you want to become a video game designer or programmer or a character artist, you should consider the bachelor’s degree program.
